Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue ".NET 6 not listed besides .NET Core 3.1 /5.0" (#9005) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

.NET 6 not listed for Tool and class library targeting .NET 6, but .NET 5 and .NET Core 3.1 is. 

Example tool 
![Screenshot_20220215-224750](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1647294/154156200-abb96ccd-62d5-4b98-9805-2c4c2516c524.jpg)

Example class library
![Screenshot_20220215-225722](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1647294/154156592-f4fde3d8-ae61-44a5-9d1f-76dbf7a57e89.jpg)


Both have .NET 6 listed under frameworks
![Screenshot_20220215-230030](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1647294/154156782-422dc4bb-9c71-4d38-b91e-e20bf89cb411.jpg)


### Repro Steps

Go to
https://www.nuget.org/packages/Cake.Tool
or
https://www.nuget.org/packages/Cake.Core

### Expected Behavior

.NET 6 to be listed

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Gallery should show which frameworks a package is compatible with" (#4843) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The NuGet web site (and client UI) doesn't *really* show which frameworks a package is compatible with. Instead, it renders the dependency groups. If there are no dependency groups, it doesn't show any frameworks:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5169960/31554645-04ba4bdc-aff3-11e7-9dc2-cba00c2562e5.png)

And if there are some, it quickly looks super busy, even in packages with few dependencies (check out [JSON.NET](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/)). And for meta packages it's basically not working at all (check out [NETStandard.Library](https://www.nuget.org/packages/NETStandard.Library)).

If think we want to render the lowest version of a framework that the package is compatible with. We probably also want to hide or at least deemphasize legacy frameworks:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5169960/31554441-6fae0cd6-aff2-11e7-939e-5206cf1699b3.png)

If my package only targets .NET Standard, I should still see the list of frameworks I’m effectively compatible with (i.e. the list above). Ideally, the list of frameworks would remain the same between packages but we’d indicate unsupported ones. For instance, let’s say the package only targets .NET Framework 2.0, this is what I would expect to see:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5169960/31554451-7534c4ce-aff2-11e7-96c8-116496f55a84.png)

Logically, I think we want to have a list of frameworks on the server for which we do hit testing with each package. Adding new frameworks should update the display for all packages.

## .NET Standard

We probably want to treat .NET Standard specially, at least by displaying it first. If a package has .NET Framework assets, it might be consumable via the .NET Standard 2.0 compatibility mode. It seems we should think if and how we could render that information. Maybe like this?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5169960/31555337-8544e7a6-aff5-11e7-8924-1217fa9a91ca.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Better error message when uploading a certificate fails" (#9003) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

_No response_

### The Elevator Pitch

The error message when uploading a certificate to the gallery that doesn't meet requirements isn't particularly helpful:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1020407/154065380-17d5b45b-51c7-4aea-ac3d-9223fad36f11.png)

It tells you what you need, but not how what you uploaded wasn't correct or how to get from what you uploaded to what you need. While someone who's experienced with security tools like OpenSSL can likely take what they have and convert it to the requested format without too much trouble, this could be a very confusing and time-consuming process of research and trial-and-error for developers who aren't experienced with certificates. This could eventually lead to them giving up on signing packages or carrying out unsafe actions in pursuit of answers (I.e. using untrusted web-based certificate conversion tools and accidentally leaking their private key). It's in the interest of the entire NuGet ecosystem to ensure package authors can sign and validate packages as easily and painlessly as possible.

There are a few ways I think this experience could be improved:
- Tell the user what they uploaded. While it may take some additional code to determine the kind and format of a certificate that the gallery can't handle, it would give the user a much better starting point for researching how to convert it to the appropriate format. There are so many different starting points, and the extensions can mean so many different things, just understanding what you have in your hand is a huge help.
- Link to a general overview of how security certificates work like [this one](https://www.ssl.com/guide/pem-der-crt-and-cer-x-509-encodings-and-conversions/). 
- Suggest that the user import their certificate into the Windows Certificate Manager MMC snap-in and then export it from there. This could be some simple inline text, at least enough to suggest it's something worth researching, and/or a link to a full article [like this](https://support.globalsign.com/ssl/ssl-certificates-installation/import-and-export-certificate-microsoft-windows). I'd also mention that the private key _does not_ need to be exported with the certificate here.
- Suggest that the user use OpenSSL either through WSL or on Linux. This doesn't need to include OpenSSL commands for all types of conversions, but even just mentioning that this is an available tool that can help convert to the correct certificate format for upload could help start the user down the right path.

Another related mitigation beyond better help text could be to accept more certificate formats, thus reducing the number of failures requiring better text up front. For example, accepting a PEM encoded certificate in addition to DER.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Using nuget.core 2.14.0 with https://www.nuget.org/api/v2 no longer allows finding packages." (#9000) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

We are using NuGet.Core 2.14.0 with https://www.nuget.org/api/v2 and yesterday we started experiencing an error blocking finding packages.

We are getting the following exception on almost all packages we try to find using FindPackages(...)
System.InvalidOperationException: Response version '3.0' is not supported. The only supported versions are: '1.0', '2.0'.

This happens both in Azure and locally.

We are in the process of updating to a newer version of nuget but it would be nice to get this fixed.

### Repro Steps

You can also reporduce this manually by for example doing doing a manual request in browser:

1. https://packages.nuget.org/api/v2/FindPackagesById()?id='System.Runtime.Serialization.Primitives'&version='4.1.1'
2. Check Response Headers.
3. DataServiceVersion: 3.0 is returned.

### Expected Behavior

Expected behaviour would be to return a version of DataServices that still works with NuGet.Core 2 when using v2 feed.

### Screenshots

Problem when using NuGet.Core
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6636662/153552470-e9d14f01-efdd-4a9c-a17a-4d3ef2f38424.png)

Manual repro:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6636662/153591105-e3b0ba64-20cd-4ee2-b972-8a9dd49e32bf.png)


### Additional Context and logs

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "GitHubVulnerabilities2Db broken by a dependency change" (#9002) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The current build of GitHubVulnerabilities2Db will not run (it fails with an assembly load error on NuGetGallery.Core). Currently deployed build is from June 2022, so a break has been introduces since then. Possibly this PR: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8740/files. 

The AI on a deployment of the current build indicates ObjectDisposed exceptions on System.Net.Http.HttpClient in the GraphQL iterator, but a local build showed the assembly load issue. Requires some more investigation.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Bug Fix] Packages with empty descriptions cause HTTP 500 on reflows" (#9001) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4218

Packages with empty descriptions (empty string), when reflowed, see their description parsed as `null`, which triggers an HTTP 500 on the Package Details page.

_NOTE:_ New packages cannot be uploaded with empty descriptions, these packages were already in the system, probably from before these validation checks were enabled.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Plugin model for post-package add" (#11597) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console, dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

NuGet allows for a package to be added to a project, but does not enable post-add steps.  This used to exist with the model of `install.ps1` but that is no longer available.  There are many scenarios where this is desired, but the current solutions (msbuild targets) does not complete the experience.  NuGet should make available a renewed model for post-package add configuration in some type of plugin model that enables packages to augment the experience when adding.  Right now the users who only use tools like VS Package Manager UI don't get a pleasant experience when adding packages that actually **require** post-add steps to be meaningful and the PM UI experience doesn't expose/alert them to such.  The experience does not put the developer on the path of success and in some cases it puts them into the pit of failure.

### Additional Context and Details

Razor components in ASPNET are one such category here.  Nearly every Razor component will follow the pattern of asking the user to do the following:

- Add the package
- Modify their _Imports.razor file to include an additional import
- Modify their index.html file to add links to the embedded CSS/JS files as a part of the component
- Modify their Program/Startup.cs files to register new DI services that may be required for the component to work

When a developer does the first step...especially in VS...they aren't guided to know the other steps are needed unless they are able to navigate successfully to the docs.  Otherwise they will be in an F5 loop, change something, fail, add the other thing, fail, repeat until they find success.

Compared to something analogous like the Vue framework which when you add a UI component (akin to a Razor component), it adds the package and also enables a hook to modify what is needed.  In the Vue model, you are immediately put on the path of success.  Here is an example showing a new Vue app and me adding a cool UI component library...observe the end state shows that all is modified for me to be successful:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4821/154180697-78863835-7ea4-473b-8fad-991780001722.mp4

Observe that the after state has all the requirements for me to be immediately successful.

Compare that to Razor+NuGet:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4821/154181509-9543cc15-9283-458b-b156-f2d71e92e5e9.mp4

Observe the after state has only added the package and I still need 4 more steps to be successful but there also is no information even telling me that.  I now have to modify three things and in this particular example I'll still get an error until I realize I have to add 2 more things that weren't told to me.  It's just a poorer experience.

Providing a better experience for authors to enable post-install steps would enable this scenario easily and others that have already been reported.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: All the checked sources will be unchecked after pressing Up/Down button in Options dialog" (#11577) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Release-5.11.x\5.11.1.15

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

### Details about Problem
VS Version: D16.11\32208.345
NuGet Version: Release-5.11.x\5.11.1.15
OS Version: Windows-11-Enterprise-21H2

### Repro steps
1. Launch VS and create a C# Console Application (.NET Core 6.0) project.
2. Open PM UI, click the Settings button and go to Options->NuGet Package Manager->Package Sources.
3. Make sure some sources has already been checked.
4. Select any package source in the list and press Up/Down button.

### Expected
The checked status will not be changed.
### Actual
All the checked sources will be unchecked as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/153188144-d9272733-ee98-45d3-8815-629e4778f294.png)
### Notes
1.It doesn’t happen on + and X button.
2.It doesn’t repro on 17.1 Preview6 and 17.2 Preview1.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "AutoCompleteResourceV3 does not use the supplied logger" (#11272) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe

### Product Version

NuGet.Client (v4.2.0), tested with .NET Core SDK 5.0.104

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Hi.

I maintain a [VS Code extension[(https://github.com/tintoy/msbuild-project-tools-vscode/) that uses the NuGet autocomplete API, and was having trouble diagnosing the cause of AutoComplete failure for Azure DevOps package sources (it works, and has always worked, for other package sources). I created a console app to perform the AutoComplete request (while capturing any logs created by the NuGet client). I would have expected to see at least _some_ log entries from NuGet which is what made me go looking in the client library source code. As it turns out, the client library ignores the supplied logger and always uses `NullLogger.Instance`.

The code in question:

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Protocol/Resources/AutoCompleteResourceV3.cs#L55

And here's the code I was using where I would have expected it to use the supplied logger:

https://gist.github.com/tintoy/3d9467d59b2547ad227ba5d1560ee838#file-program-cs-L61

I'm happy to open a PR for this if you folks don't have the time to fix it but I thought I'd better talk to you first to see what you think 🙂 

### Verbose Logs

```shell
[Program/INF] Requesting suggestions for package prefix Microsoft.AspNetCore from package source nuget.org ("https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json")...
[Program/INF] Received 20 suggestions for package prefix Microsoft.AspNetCore from package source nuget.org ("https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json").
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Abstractions
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Hosting.Server.Abstractions
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Hosting.Abstractions
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.WebUtilities
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Extensions
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Routing
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Abstractions
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Routing.Abstractions
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authorization
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.JsonPatch
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.ResponseCaching.Abstractions
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.Abstractions
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authentication.Core
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Formatters.Json
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.DataAnnotations
[Program/INF]   Suggested package: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authorization.Policy
```
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: NuGet tooling to view package prefix reservation" (#11594) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console, MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

With package source mapping, you can establish a 1-N relationship between a package identity and a source. 
When using package prefix patterns, you may want to consider things like, is this prefix reserved on nuget.org, and use that as a means to make a decision. 

For example, one would want to know given a package id, where it's prefix is reserved, or if so, which one. 

Note that there might not be easy ways to get this data from the servers, so this might span client + server.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add `--all` option for dotnet list package" (#11551) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently customer have to make 2 separate queries to find out both `outdated` and `vulnerable` packages with `dotnet list package`, instead we need `--all` which shows all deprecated, vulnerable, and outdated top level and transitive packages

https://github.com/NuGet/Home/pull/11446#discussion_r766860629

I'm including screenshot given GH is not good at tracking comments/discussion.
![image.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5eb1d84a3cd56675c3efe510/b416b4ff-8189-424a-8aec-e315e8aad49b)
